SN 0253-6730
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Discoidella niculaei; Palaeocypridina agighiolensis; Palaeocypridina
   tulceaensis [Romania /  / new species] [Triassic /  / ]. 
   Palaeocypridina [Triassic /  / New genus]. 
   Podocopa [Fossil assemblages /  / New record; systematics] [Romania /
   Dobrogea / stratigraphical distribution] [Triassic / Early & Middle
   Anisian / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Ostracoda

   Triassic, P. 514; Fossil]. 
   Palaeocypridina - Crasquin 2013 (Ostracoda): [Gen nov, Of family
   Cypridinellidae, Type species Palaeocypridina tulceaensis, p. 514,
   Triassic; Fossil]. 
   Palaeocypridina agighiolensis - Sebe 2013 (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, Romania,
   Triassic, P. 515; Fossil].

DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Ostracodes from the Albian of Landes (SW France): taxonomy,
   biostratigraphy and palaeobiogeography.
FT Ostracodes de l'Albien des Landes (Sud-Ouest de la France) : taxonomie,
   biostratigraphie et paleobiogeographie.
AU Sauvagnat, Jacques (jsauvagnat@ebogri.com) 
   Colin, Jean-Paul
SO Revue de Paleobiologie
VL 32
IS 2
PS 541-556
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eighteen species of ostracodes have been recognized in boreholes on the
   Landes Department, SW France. Seven new species are described, nine have
   been identified and assigned to described species and two remain in open
   nomenclature. Early and Middle Albian associations present affinities
   with the Boreal realm whereas the uppermost Albian ones possess species
   in common with the Iberian peninsula.

PT J
AN ZOOR15012073462
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI New ostracodes of the Paleogene of Sine-Saloum (Senegal, West Africa):
   biostratigraphy, paleoenvironment.
FT Ostracodes nouveaux du Paleogene du Sine-Saloum (Senegal, Afrique de
   l'Ouest): biostratigraphie, paleoenvironnement.
AU Sarr, Raphael (mbundor52@yahoo.fr) 
SO Revue de Paleobiologie
VL 32
IS 2
PS 569-588
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB A general stratigraphic framework and detailed planktonic biozonation of
   Paleogene formations (P1-E13 zones of Danian to Bartonian) of the
   Sine-Saloum area is established for the first time from samples of 5
   water-wells. Samples yielded a rich and diversified ostracode fauna of
   135 species: 19 of them are found for the first time in Senegal and 18
   are newly described. New species are Aysegulina mbassisensis, A.
   papillata, Costa? deklaszi, Cytherelloidea saloumensis, Dahomeya
   reticulata, Eocytheropteron mbeyensis, E. yoroensis, Hazelina?
   foundiougnensis, Hermanites? pustulosa, Loxoconcha? ngolothiensis,
   Orthonotacythere spinata, Schizocythere wiedmanni, Pokornyella
   lagandongi, Protobuntonia baolensis, Puriana sokonensis, Urocythereis
   castelaini, U. sinesaloumensis et Uromuellerina guiraudi. Ostracode
   associations provide evidence of predominant lagoonal and coastal
   environment during the Danian that evolved to a shallow carbonate
   platform in the Thanetian. Outer-shelf environment prevailed during the
   Ypresian transgression. From latest Ypresian to Bartonian an inner-shelf
   with reefs environment prevailed in Sine-Saloum area, attesting a sea
   level decrease.
C1 Sarr, Raphael; Univ Cheikh Anta Diop Dakar, Fac Sci & Tech, BP 5005,
   Dakar, Senegal, Senegal.
EM mbundor52@yahoo.fr
SC Zoology; Paleontology

AB The type specimens from the Beetle Collection (DUBC) deposited in
   Daugavpils University (Daugavpils, Latvia) are listed: 67 type specimens
   of 41 species from seven families (Carabidae, Anobiidae, Staphylinidae,
   Scarabaeidae, Melandryidae, Cerambycidae, Chrysomelidae). Two new

   thoracicus Wiedemann, 1823 = B. (s.str.) indicus Anichtchenko, 2012 syn.
   n. and Syntomus truncatellus (Linne, 1761) = S. ai Barsevskis, 1993 syn.

DT Article
TI Early Bashkirian Rugosa (Anthozoa) from the Donets Basin, Ukraine. Part
   4. Cordibia, a new protocolonial genus.
AU Fedorowski, Jerzy (jerzy@amu.edu.pl) 
   Ogar, Viktor V.
SO Acta Geologica Polonica
VL 63
IS 3
PS 297-314
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB Cordibia pumila gen. et sp.nov. (Aulophyllidae, Dibunophyllinae) from
   the Lower Bashkirian E1 Limestone of the Donets Basin, Ukraine is
   described. The term "protocolony" is formally defined as a growth form
   intermediate between the solitary and colonial. Protocolonies consist of
   protocorallites and verticils of non-reproductive offsets (i.e., the
   lost structures). The early ontogeny of a protocorallite is compared to
   the blastogeny in the same species in order to establish characters in
   common during both processes and to document the usefulness of
   blastogeny for phylogenetic reconstructions. The short duration and
   abundance of the occurrence (Limestones E1up acme, E11 ) of that species
   also makes it a good marker for the lowest Feninian (= Krasnopolyanian)
   strata in the Donets Basin.
C1 Fedorowski, Jerzy; Adam Mickiewicz Univ, Inst Geol, Makow Polnych 16,
   Poznan, PL-61606, Poland, Poland.
EM jerzy@amu.edu.pl
RI Ogar, Victor/H-9474-2018
OI Ogar, Victor/0000-0002-7566-3648
SC Zoology
SN 0001-5709
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological
   time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Cordibia [Carboniferous /  / New genus]. 
   Cordibia pumila [Ukraine /  / new species] [Carboniferous /  / ]. 
   Dibunophyllinae [Ukraine / Donets Basin / stratigraphical distribution;
   systematics] [Carboniferous / Early Bashkirian / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Zoantharia, Rugosa
OR Cordibia (Rugosa): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Dibunophyllinae, Type species
   Cordibia pumila, p. 302, Carboniferous; Fossil]. 
   Cordibia cylindricum - (Dobrolyubova 1937) (Rugosa): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Dibunophyllum, p. 302]. 
   Cordibia pumila (Rugosa): [Sp nov, Ukraine, Carboniferous, P. 303;
   Fossil]. 
   Dibunophyllinae - Wang 1950 (Rugosa): [Fossil]. 
   Dibunophyllum cylindricum - Dobrolyubova 1937 (Rugosa): [Referred to,
   New genus Cordibia, p. 302].

DT Article
TI Palaeontology, taxonomic revision and variability of some species of the
   genus Gassendiceras Bert et al., 2006 (Ammonitina, Upper Barremian) from
   southeastern France.
AU Bert, Didier
   Bersac, Stephane
   Delanoy, Gerard
   Canut, Leon
SO Acta Geologica Polonica
VL 63
IS 3
PS 355-397
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Bed-by-bed sampling of twelve Barremian sections in southeastern France
   from pelagic basin (Vocontian Basin) to neritic platforms (Arc of
   Castellane, Arc of Nice and Provencal Domain) has enabled the collection
   of isochronous samples of the ammonite genus Gassendiceras. Three poorly
   known species of the Toxancyloceras vandenheckei Zone (Upper Barremian)
   are revised: G. alpinum, G. multicostatum and G. hoheneggeri; two new
   species are described (G. rebouleti nov. sp. and G. bosellii nov. sp.).
   The intraspecific variability of particular species was recognised. This
   variability is between slender peramorphic and robust paedomorphic
   extreme morphologies, with the presence of all intermediates.
C1 Bert, Didier; Lab Grp Rech Paleobiol & Biostratig Ammonites GPA,
   Quartier St Joseph, La Mure Argens, F-04170, France, France.
SC Zoology
SN 0001-5709

   species] [France /  / ] [Cretaceous /  / ] [ /  / ].

   designated, P. 368]. 
   Emericiceras barremense multicostata - Sarkar 1955 (Lytoceratida):
   [Lectotype designated, P. 370]. 
   Gassendiceras - Bert, Delanoy & Bersac 2006 (Lytoceratida): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 367; Fossil].

   diagnosis, P. 370].

DT Article
TI Scaphitid ammonites from the Upper Cretaceous of KwaZulu-Natal and
   Eastern Cape Province, South Africa.
AU Kennedy, William James (jim.kennedy@oum.ox.ac.uk) 
   Klinger, Herbert Christian
SO Acta Geologica Polonica
VL 63
IS 4
PS 527-543
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Scaphitid ammonites are described and illustrated from the Upper
   Cretaceous of the coastal region of north-eastern SouthAfrica. Scaphites
   kieslingswaldensis Langenhan mid Grundey. 1891, Scaphites manasoaensis
   Collignon, 1965, and Yezoites concinna sp. nov. occur in the Coniacian
   part of the St Lucia Formation in northern KwaZulu-Natal. A further
   Yezoites sp. may also be from this level. Argentoscaphites corrugatus
   sp. no occurs in the Santonian to Lower Campanian Mzamba Formation on
   the northernmost coast of Eastern Cape Province. Yezoires australis sp.
   nov. occurs in the Upper Santonian part of the St Lucia mid Mzamba
   formations of these areas, mid Scaphites recsidei Collignon, 1969, is
   recorded from the Lower Campanian part of the Mzamba Formation. The
   scaphitid assemblage includes species previously described from Western
   Europe and Madagascar, together with Argentoscaphites. previously known
   only from Patagonia (and possibly South India). Dimorphism is recognised
   in Scaphites recsidei. Yezoites concinna sp. no and Y australis sp. nov.
   Argentoscaphites corrugatus sp. nov. and Yezoites sp. are represented by
   microconchs only. Dimorphism has not been recognised in Scaphites
   kieslingswaldensis.
C1 Kennedy, William James; Univ Oxford, Museum Nat Hist, Parks Rd, Oxford,
   OX1 3W, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM jim.kennedy@oum.ox.ac.uk
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0001-5709
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region; Africa; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Argentoscaphites corrugatus; Yezoites australis; Yezoites concinna
   [South Africa /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Scaphitidae [Fossil assemblages /  / Systematics] [South Africa / Cape
   Province, east & KwaZulu-Natal / stratigraphical distribution]
   [Cretaceous / Upper Cretaceous / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda, Ammonoidea, Lytoceratida
OR Argentoscaphites corrugatus (Lytoceratida): [Sp nov, South Africa,
   Cretaceous, P. 535; Fossil]. 
   Scaphitidae - Gill 1871 (Lytoceratida): [Fossil]. 
   Yezoites australis (Lytoceratida): [Sp nov, South Africa, Cretaceous, P.
   538; Fossil]. 
   Yezoites concinna (Lytoceratida): [Sp nov, South Africa, Cretaceous, P.
   537; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR15011059272
DT Article
TI Oyster-bioimmured ammonites from the Upper Albian of Annopol, Poland:
   stratigraphic and palaeobiogeographic implications.
AU Machalski, Marcin (mach@twarda.pan.pl) 
   Kennedy, William J.
SO Acta Geologica Polonica
VL 63
IS 4
PS 545-554
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Ammonites Mortoniceras (Subschloenbachia) sp. are preserved as
   attachment scars on the oyster shells from the topmost portion of the
   Albian succession at Annopol, Poland. These oyster-bioimmured ammonites
   show a closest affinity to the representatives offiloilonicei.ris
   (Subschloenbachia) characteristic of the upper Upper Albian perinflatum
   zone. No ammonites indicative of the uppermost Albian lowermost
   Cenomanian Pracschlocnbachia briacensis Zone are recorded. Thus, the
   hiatus at the Albian Cenomanian boundary at Annopol embraces the latter
   zone. The presence (and dominance) of Mortonicerris in the upper Upper
   Albian ammonite assemblage ofAnnopol suggests that the representatives
   of this Tethyan genus could migrate into the epicratonic areas of Poland
   directly from the Tethyan Realm, pia the Lwow (Lviv) region.
C1 Machalski, Marcin; Polish Acad Sci, Inst Paleobiol, Ul Twarda 51-55,
   Warsaw, PL-00818, Poland, Poland.
EM mach@twarda.pan.pl
RI Machalski, Marcin/AAX-1074-2020
OI Machalski, Marcin/0000-0002-1121-4093
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 0001-5709
BD Ecology; Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe;
   Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Mortoniceras (Subschloenbachia) [Fossil assemblages /  / new record]
   [Fossilization / Oyster bioimmuration / ] [Zoogeography /
   Palaeobiogeography / ] [Poland / Annopol / stratigraphical distribution]
   [Cretaceous / Upper Albian / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda, Ammonoidea, Ammonitida
OR Mortoniceras (Subschloenbachia) (Ammonitida): [Fossil; New record].

TI Vojnovskytesidae - a new family of Mississippian Rugosa (Anthozoa).
AU Fedorowski, Jerzy (jerzy@amu.edu.pl) 
   Kullmann, Juergen
SO Acta Geologica Polonica
VL 63
IS 4
PS 657-679
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Vojnovskytes Fedorowski, 2009, namely V.
   marcinowskii and V. arcuatus, and a new genus, Vojnimitor., based on the
   new species V proiectus, all from Mississippian strata of northern
   Spain, are described. Vojnovskytes variabilis (Vojnovsky-Krieger, 1934),
   the type species for the genus from the lowermost Visean strata of
   southern Urals, also is discussed and illustrated. Characters displayed
   by the taxa mentioned permit introduction of a new family
   Vojnovskytesidae.
C1 Fedorowski, Jerzy; Adam Mickiewicz Univ, Inst Geol, Makow Polnych 16,
   Poznan, PL-61606, Poland, Poland.
EM jerzy@amu.edu.pl

TI Description of two new Ceratophyus (Coleoptera: Geotrupidae) species
   from the Mediterranean region along with annotated checklist of the
   genus.
AU Hillert, Oliver (o.hillert@yahoo.de) 
   Kral, David
SO Acta Societatis Zoologicae Bohemicae
VL 77
IS 3-4
PS 173-186
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Ceratophyus schaffrathi sp. nov. from the Island of Kos, Greece and C.
   maghrebinicus sp. nov. from Libya and Algeria are described and their
   diagnostic characters are illustrated. Identification key to the
   Mediterranean Ceratophyus Fischer von Waldheim, 1824 species is provided
   and annotated checklist of the genus Ceratophyus is compiled. First
   country records of C. sinicus Zunino, 1973 for Mongolia (Domogovi Aimag
   province) and C. sulcicornis (Fairmaire, 1887) for the Indian states of
   Arunachal Pradesh and West Bengal are given.

IS 3-4
PS 187-202
PD 2013

AB The Philonthus maculipennis species group of the genus Philontluts
   Stephens, 1829, is proposed, containing 11 species, two species are
   described as new: Philonthus lanius sp. n. (Cameroon), P. synodontis sp.
   nov. (Liberia, South Africa, Sierra Leone, Uganda), remaining nine
   species are redescribed: Philonthus constricticeps Tottenham, 1949
   (Zimbabwe), P. cruentus Bernhauer, 1915 (Tanzania), P. ischnocerus

   Republic), R smaragdinus Tottenham, 1949 (Democratic Republic of the

   from the genus Gabrius Stephens, 1829: Philonthus jacksoni (Cameron,
   1950) comb. nov. All species of the R maculipennis species group are
   keyed, the aedeagi and relevant morphological characters of all species
   are figured.

DT Article
TI Revision of Afrotropical species of the Philonthus rudipennis species
   group (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Philonthina).
AU Hromadka, Lubomir (hromadkal@seznam.cz) 
SO Acta Societatis Zoologicae Bohemicae
VL 77
IS 3-4
PS 203-252
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Philonthus rudipennis species group of the genus Philonthus
   Stephens, 1829, is proposed, containing 40 species, 18 species are
   described as new: Philonthus bitis sp. nov. (Democratic Republic of the
   Congo), P bleda sp. nov. (Rwanda), P breviceps sp. nov. (Democratic
   Republic of the Congo), P creopsis sp. nov. (Democratic Republic of the
   Congo), P flavomaculatus sp. nov. (Ethiopia), P jaculus sp. nov. (South
   Africa), P. maleunius sp. nov. (Gabon), P mormyrops sp. nov. (Malawi), P
   nycteris sp. nov. (Democratic Republic of the Congo), P pandion sp. nov.
   (Liberia), P papyrocranus sp. nov. (Ethiopia), P pareutropicus (South
   Africa), P pedetes sp. nov. (Tanzania), P raphicerus sp. nov. (Nigeria),
   P. rhinopoma sp. nov. (Chad), P scotopelia sp. nov. (Rwanda),
   tachymarptis sp. nov. (Democratic Republic of the Congo), P threskiornis
   sp. nov. (South Africa). Twenty two species group taxa are redescribed:
   Philonthus altivagans Fauvel, 1907, P banalis Tottenham, 1962, P belesis
   Tottenham, 1956, P coiffaitianus Levasseur, 1980, P csiki Bemhauer,
   1917, P diabolicus Cameron, 1942, P dichrous Tottenham, 1962, P
   iridescens Tottenham, 1949, P leyei Levasseur, 1980, P mifanus
   Tottenham, 1956, P. musonoiensis Levasseur, 1966, P. nigricolor Cameron,
   1942, P nimeaglius Tottenham, 1962, P obliviosus Levasseur, 1968,P.
   pellax Tottenham 1955,P. praetor Tottenham, 1949, P rudipennis Fauvel,
   1907,P subaeneicollis Bernhauer, 1931, P upotowts Tottenham, 1962, P.
   usambaricus Bernhauer, 1937, P vittiger vittiger Fauvel, 1907, P
   vittiger pseudovittiger Bemhauer, 1939. Philonthus rubrovittatus
   Tottenham, 1939 syn. nov., is synonymized with P. usambaricus Bemhauer,
   1937. An identification key to all species of the species group is
   provided and male genitalia and significant morphological characters are
   ilustrated.

   Czech Republic.

TI Description of a new Sinaphodius species from Laos along with a
   checklist of the genus (Coleptera: Scarabaeidae: Aphodiinae: Aphodiini).
AU Mencl, Ladislav (l.mencl@centrum.cz) 
   Rakovic, Miloslav
   Kral, David
SO Acta Societatis Zoologicae Bohemicae
VL 77
IS 3-4
PS 253-264
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the subfamily Aphodiinae, Sinaphodius natalicizis sp.
   nov. from Laos, is described and illustrated. Detailed photos of the
   most similar and probably related, S. chitwanensis (Schoolmeesters et
   Van den Heuvel, 1999), are also presented to make possible comparison of
   the two species. A checklist of the genus Sinaphodius Cervenka, 1994 is
   provided.

PT J

DT Article
TI Gall midges (Diptera: Cecidomyiidae) of Georgia.
AU Skuhrava, Marcela (skuhrava@quick.cz) 
   Skuhravy, Vaclav
   Bunr, Hans Juergen
SO Acta Societatis Zoologicae Bohemicae
VL 77
IS 3-4
PS 271-309
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The gall midge fauna of Georgia is composed of 123 species belonging to
   47 genera. Of them 12 species are identified to the genus level: two
   species to Asphondylia Loew, 1850, two species to Contarinia Rondani,
   1860, two species to Dasineura Rondani, 1840, one species to Ephedromyia
   Marikovskij, 1953, one species to Mikiola Kieffer, 1896, and one species
   to Spurgia Gagne, 1990. 82 gall midge species are new members of the
   gall midge fauna of Georgia; their galls were found by H. J. Buhr at 30
   localities in central and eastern Georgia in the years 2004-2013. An
   annotated list of all species of gall midges and a list of host plants
   and associated with gall midges are given. Galls of 60 species of gall
   midges on their host plants are shown in colour photos. The gall midge
   fauna of Georgia is relatively rich and similar in composition and
   species numbers with that ofArmenia; both countries are shared by 40
   common species. Zoogeographical analysis: 38% are European, 22%
   Eurosiberian, 18% Euro-Asian, 5% Holarctic and 2% alien species.
   Contarinia desertorum Marikovskij, 1961, causing galls on Alhagi
   pseudoalhagi (Bieb.) Desv., Psectrosema barbatum (Marikovskij, 1961) and
   P. turkmenicum Mamaev et Becknazharova, 1983, associated with Tamarix
   L., Spiromyia cystiphorae (Fedotova, 1985) and Tavolgomyia karelini
   (Fedotova, 1982) with Spiraea hypericifolia L. are Turanian species
   originating from Central Asia. Mikiola orientalis Kieffer, 1908 and
   Mikiola sp. causing galls on leaves of Fagus orientalis Lipsky,
   Rabdophaga gemmicolata Gagne, 2004, causing galls on Salix triandra L.
   and Sophoromyia armeniaca Mamaev et Mirumian, 1989, inducing galls on
   leaflets of Glycyrrhiza glabra L., are Caucasian species. Janetiella
   fi-ankumi Harris, 2003, inducing galls on stems of Rosa spinosissima L.,
   is a rare species, firstly recorded after its description. Contarinia
   loti (De Geer, 1776), causing galls on Lotus pedunculatus Cav., was
   found at the highest situated locality of Georgia, at Kazbegi, at an
   altitude of 2191 m a. s. 1.. In Georgia two alien species were recorded:
   Dasineura gleditchiae (Osten Sacken, 1886), causing galls on leaflets of
   Gleditsia triacanthos L., and Obolodiplosis robiniae (Haldeman, 1847),
   inducing galls on leaflets of Robinia psemioacacia L. Both species
   originate from Neartics. Relation to host plants: gall midges are
   associated with 102 plant species which belong to 40 plant families; of
   them 30% are trees and shrubs and 70% herbaceous plants. Most gall midge
   species (15) are associated with Fabaceae. Usually only one species of
   gall midges is associated with one host plant species. Each of three
   tree, Betula litwinowii Doluch, Fraxinus excelsior L. and Fagus
   sylvatica L., host three gall midge species.
C1 Skuhrava, Marcela; Bitovska 1227, Praha, CZ-14000, Czech Republic, Czech
   Republic.
EM skuhrava@quick.cz
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1211-376X
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Cecidomyiidae [Plant hosts /  / new record] [Zoogeography /  / ]
   [Georgia-Asia /  / distribution; faunal list]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera
OR Cecidomyiidae (Nematocera): [Parasite; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15011063873
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15011063356
DT Article
TI A re-appraisal of species diversity within the Australian grasswrens
   Amytornis (Aves: Maluridae).
AU Christidis, Les (les.christidis@gmail.com) 
   Rheindt, Frank E.
   Boles, Walter E.
   Norman, Janette A.
SO Australian Zoologist
VL 36
IS 4
PS 429-437
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The Australian grasswrens (Amytornis) comprise a genus of cryptically
   plumaged species inhabiting the arid regions of southern, western,
   central, and northern Australia. Isolated, fragmented populations
   characterise the distributional pattern of several species, whereas
   others appear to show ecophenotypic clinal variation in plumage
   patterns. These features have made the species-level taxonomy of the
   genus a matter of ongoing debate. We undertook qualitative
   considerations of morphological, biogeographical and ecological features
   in combination with quantitative DNA distance measures from published
   studies, to provide a comprehensive species level revision of Amytornis.
   In addition to the ten species recognised by Schodde and Mason (1999)
   (housei, textilis, goyderi, purnelli, ballarae, merrotsyi, woodwardi,
   dorotheae, striatus, barbatus), we also recognise as species the
   following: modestus, rowleyi, oweni and whitei. These fourteen species
   are placed into four subgenera: Amytornis, Magnamytis, Maluropsis and
   Cryptamytis subgen. nov. The latter subgenus is erected for A.
   merrotsyi. The potential impacts that this new taxonomy will have on the
   conservation status of the various taxa are canvassed.
C1 Christidis, Les; So Cross Univ, Natl Marine Sci Ctr, Coffs Harbour, NSW,
   2450, Australia, Australia.
EM les.christidis@gmail.com
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Biodiversity &Conservation; Zoology;
   Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0067-2238
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Conservation; General morphology; Integument; Integumentary
   derivatives; Ecology; Community structure; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Australasia
DE Amytornis [Conservation / Conservation implications / systematics]
   [General morphology /  / ] [Plumage / Plumage patterns / ] [Species
   diversity /  / ] [Zoogeography / Biogeography / ] [Australia /  / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Passeriformes, Maluridae
OR Amytornis - Stejneger 1885 (Maluridae). 
   Amytornis (Cryptamytis) (Maluridae): [Subgen nov, Type species Amytornis
   merrotsyi merrotsyi, p. 435]. 
   Amytornis barbatus barbatus (Maluridae): [Referred to, Subgenus
   Amytornis (Maluropsis), p. 434]. 
   Amytornis dorotheae (Maluridae): [Referred to, Subgenus Amytornis
   (Magnamytis), p. 435]. 
   Amytornis merrotsyi merrotsyi (Maluridae): [Designated type species for
   new subgenus, Amytornis (Cryptamytis), p. 435]. 
   Amytornis merrotsyi pedleri (Maluridae): [Referred to, New subgenus
   Amytornis (Cryptamytis), p. 435]. 
   Amytornis oweni (Maluridae): [Referred to, Subgenus Amytornis
   (Magnamytis), p. 435]. 
   Amytornis rowleyi (Maluridae): [Referred to, Subgenus Amytornis
   (Magnamytis), p. 435]. 
   Amytornis striatus (Maluridae): [Referred to, Subgenus Amytornis
   (Magnamytis), p. 435]. 
   Amytornis whitei (Maluridae): [Referred to, Subgenus Amytornis
   (Magnamytis), p. 435]. 
   Amytornis woodwardi (Maluridae): [Referred to, Subgenus Amytornis
   (Magnamytis), p. 435]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15011063356

DT Article
TI A new Gnathoncus Jacquelin do Val, 1858 from Iran (Imsecta, Coleoptera,
   Histeridae).
FT Un nuovo Gnathoncus Jacquelin du Val, 1858 dell'iran (insecta,
   Coleoptera, Histeridae).
AU Vienna, Pierpaolo (p.vien@libero.it) 
   Ratto, Giovanni
SO Bollettino del Museo di Storia Naturale di Venezia
VL 64
PS 29-37
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 1
AB Gnathoncus inoradii, a new pholeophilous species from Iran, collected in
   burrows of rodents is described. The new species presents unique
   characteristics, including the sutural stria of elytra placed in a
   median position, as in the Afrotropical G. umbrettarum Therond, 1952 and
   in the Oriental G. vietnamicus Kryzhanovskij, 1972.

DT Article
TI DESCRIPTION OF THREE NEW SPECIES OF DRAPETIS MEIGEN, 1822 FROM TUSCANY
   (ITALY), WITH KEY TO SPECIES OF THE GENUS FROM WESTERN EUROPE (INSECTA,
   DIPTERA, HYBOTIDAE).
AU Raffone, Gianni (gianni_raffone@tin.it) 
SO Bollettino del Museo di Storia Naturale di Venezia
VL 64
PS 45-50
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species of Drapetis Meigen, 1822 from Tuscany (Italy), are
   described: Drapetis munarii n. sp. is related to D. flavipes Macquart,
   1834, from which it differs in having the scape and pedicel brown, 2
   prescutellar dorsocentrals, 4 intra-alars, 8 supra-alars, and the
   morphology of the male terminalia; Drapetis knutsoni n. sp. is related
   to D. flavipes Macquart, 1834, from which it differs in having the scape
   and pedicel black, 2 prescutellar dorsocentrals, 2 intralars, 6
   supra-alars, 3 notopleurals, hind femur with 3 basally dorsal setae and
   3 ventral setulae, and the morphology of the male terminalia; Drapetis
   subparilis n. sp. is related to D. parilis (Collin, 1926), from which it
   differs in having 2 prescutellar acrostichals, 2 notopleurals, and the
   morphology of the male terminalia.

   I-30135, Italy, Italy.

PT J

DT Article
TI Recovery and restoration of a skull of Metaxytherium serresii
   (Manunalia, Dugongidae) from Cessaniti-Zungri Miocene Basin (Calabria,
   Italy).
FT Recupero e restauro di un cranio di Metaxytherium serresii (mammalia,
   Dugongidae) del bacino miocenico di Cessaniti-Zungri (calabria, italia).
AU Carone, Giuseppe mm (p.carone@libero.it) 
   Marra, Antonella Cinzia
SO Bollettino del Museo di Storia Naturale di Venezia
VL 64
PS 131-140
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A skull of Metazytherium serresii (Gervais, 1847) has been recovered in
   the Tortonian sandstones of the Cessaniti-Zungri basin (Vibo Valentia,
   Calabria, Italy), in difficult conditions caused by a little slope. The
   fossil was damaged and fragmented. Some observations carried out during
   the recovery enable considerations about taphonomy and paleoenvironment.
   The skull was isolated from the post-cranial skeleton, following a
   common pattern in marine mammals, which often float for a long time and
   underwent disarticulation and sinking of the head at first. A specimen
   of Ostrea sp. damaged the skull growing inside the cranial cavity. The
   restoration has been exacting, but gave an interesting specimen, which
   enabled morphological observations and measurements. The skull falls
   within the variability known for the species, as demonstrated by
   comparisons with specimens from Calabria, France and Libya. The restored
   specimen will be included in a morphometrical study about the new
   findings of cranial and postacranial bones of Metaxytherium serresii
   recorded in the last years in the Cessaniti-Zungri basin. Moreover, it
   will be exposed in the Municipal Museum of Palaeontology of S. Domenica
   Ricadi (Vibo Valentia), under construction.
C1 Carone, Giuseppe mm; Univ Messina, Dipartimento Sci Fis Terra, Viale
   Ferdinand Stagno Alcontres 31, Messina, I-98166, Italy, Italy.
EM p.carone@libero.it
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 2039-4160
BD Skeletal and supporting structures; Skeleton; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods
DE Metaxytherium serresii [Skull /  / Recovery & restoration] [Italy /
   Calabria, Vibo Valentia, Cessaniti-Zungri Miocene Basin / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Sirenia, Dugongidae
OR Metaxytherium serresii (Dugongidae).

DT Article
TI Bela pseudoappeliusi n. sp (Neogastropoda: Mangeliidae) from the
   Plio-Pleistocene of Italy.
AU Naldi, Francesco
   Della Bella, Giano
   Scarponi, Daniele (ceskau_czk@yahoo.it) 
SO Bollettino della Societa Paleontologica Italiana
VL 52
IS 2
PS 71-79
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of mangeliid, Bela pseudoappeliusi (Neogastropoda,
   Conoidea), is described from the Plio-Pleistocene of Italy The
   systematic description is based on a series of eleven specimens selected
   from the numerous findings in northern and central Italy (Piedmont,
   Emilia-Romagna, Tuscany and Lazio). The new species shows affinities to
   Bela (S.l.) appeliusi (Bellardi, 1877) with regard to particular
   features such as shell dimension, teleoconch sculpture and aperture
   morphology. The study includes a detailed survey of the type locality as
   well as a brief account of occurrences at other localities.

   Ambientali, Via Zamboni 67, Bologna, I-40127, Italy, Italy.

DT Article
TI Decapoalina n. gen. (Miliolata, Milioliporidae; Late Triassic), a new
   foraminiferal genus for 'Sigmoilina' schaeferae Zaninetti, Altiner,
   Dager & Ducret, 1982.
AU Gale, Luka (luka.gale@geo-zs.si) 
   Rettori, Roberto
   Martini, Rossana
   Rozic, Bostjan
SO Bollettino della Societa Paleontologica Italiana
VL 52
IS 2
PS 81-93
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB The wall of the type specimens of "Sigmoilina" schaeferae Zaninetti,
   Altiner, Dager & Ducret, 1982, described from thin sections of the
   Norian-Rhaetian reef limestone of the Taurus Mountains (Turkey),
   originally interpreted to be porcelaneous imperforate, is micritized. In
   this study, the presence of coarse pseudopores is demonstrated in the
   specimens collected from the Rhaetian Dachstein-type reef limestone of
   Mt. Begunjsica (southern Karavanke Mts, northern Slovenia) and the new
   genus Decapoalina Gale, Rettori & Martini, is established to comprise
   this particular species.

DT Article
TI First discovery of a Stenasellidae (Crustacea, Isopoda, Aselloidea) in
   the ground waters of Cameroon (Central Africa): description, origin and
   palaeogeographic implications of Metastenasellus camerounensis n. sp.
AU Togouet, Serge H. Zebaze
   Boulanouar, Mohamed
   Njine, Thomas
   Boutin, Claude (zebazehu@yahoo.fr) 
SO Bulletin de la Societe d'Histoire Naturelle de Toulouse
VL 149
PS 153-166
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The presence of an isopod crustacean belonging to the family
   Stenasellidae is reported for the first time from the ground waters of
   Cameroon (Central Africa). Metastenasellus camerounensis n. sp. have
   been sampled in several wells of the Yaounde city where water was
   characterized by a relatively low level of pollution. The new species is
   described; it shares some particular morphological traits with
   Metastenasellus leleupi and exhibits also some global but superficial
   similarities with Metastenasellus congolensis, two species from the
   Democratic Republic of Congo (former Zaire). A key to the eight species
   presently known in the genus Metastenasellus is given. The origin of the
   family Stenasellidae and of the genus Metastenasellus as well as the
   possible palaeogeographic significance of the new species in Yaounde
   area are also discussed.
C1 Boutin, Claude; 48 Rue Mouffetard, Paris, F-75005, France, France.
EM zebazehu@yahoo.fr

SN 0758-4113
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Evolution;
   Zoogeography; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa

   systematics] [Zoogeography /  / ] [Cameroon /  / ]. 
   Metastenasellus camerounensis [Cameroon /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Isopoda

DT Article
TI Parasitic Fauna of Six Species of Ornamental Freshwater Fish Species
   from the North of Iran.
AU Adel, Milad
   Ghasempour, Fatemeh
   Azizi, Hamid Reza
   Safian, Ahmad Reza
   Amiri, Armin Abedian
SO Journal of Fisheries International
VL 8
IS 3
PS 78-80
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The main objective of this study was to determine the parasitic
   infections of aquarium fish in the North of Iran. Here, 360 apparently
   ornmental fish from 6 species (each species 60 specimens) including:
   Guppy (Poecilia reticulate), gourami (Osphronemus gouramy), Swordtail
   (Xiphophorus hellerii), Platy (Xiphophorus maculates), Brachydanio rerio
   and barbs (Barbus tetrazona) was obtained from a local ornamental fish
   farm in the North of Iram during 2012-2013. Each fish was inspected and
   examined by routine methods. The parasitical infection ws studied by
   sampling from different organs. Among 360 investigated ornamental fish,
   328 fish (91.1%) were infected by at least one parasite species. In this
   study, 5 different genus including: Ichthyophtirius multifilis,
   Dactylogyrus, Gyrodactylus, Tricodina and Capillaria sp. were collected
   from 6 species. Also, Capillaria sp. was reported as a first record from
   the abdominal cavity of O. gouramy in Iram.

PT J
AN ZOOR15011058829
DT Article
TI Australia, a new journey.
FT Australie, een nieuwe reis.
AU van Leeuwen, Jeroen (jeroen.p.van.leeuwen@gmail.com) 
SO Lacerta
VL 71
IS 3
PS 92-119
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA Dutch
U1 0
U2 0
AB The author travelled in September 2012 through the states South
   Australia and especially Northern Territory. Despite the suboptimal
   climatic conditions (the nights were too cold in the south/central
   parts, generally too dry in the north), he found several interesting
   reptile and frog species. He rented a car from Adelaide airport, and
   followed largely the route Adelaide Alice Springs Katherine Darwin
   Kakadu NP Alice Springs Uluru Yorke Peninsula Adelaide. Emphasis was
   laid on the areas around Uluru-Kata Tjuta NP, Alice Springs, Nitmiluk NP
   (Katherine) and Kakadu NP, presenting a large variety of landscapes
   ranging from spinifex deserts with sand dunes to river gorges and vast
   wetlands. This also brought a large array of species. Several interest-
   ing geckos were found, among others Strophurus ciliaris and Nephrurus
   laevissimus in the southern deserts and Oedura marmorata, 0. gemmata,
   several Gehyra sp. and Heteronotia planiceps in the rocky northern
   areas. Considering agamids, the most spectacular finding was a Moloch
   horrid us on the road, while also several Lophognathus species were
   found. A Varanus giganteus was found in Kata Tjuta, while lots of
   saltwater crocs were present at the Yellow Waters in Kakadu NP. Some
   elapid snakes were found, such as Pseudonaja textilis, Pseudechis
   australis, Suta suta and Furina omata, while tree snakes (Dendrelaphis
   punctulatus) were common in the north. Despite numbers of individuals
   per species were low, it was again an amazing trip down under!
C1 van Leeuwen, Jeroen; Schaepmanstr 15, Wageningen, NL-6702 AN,
   Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM jeroen.p.van.leeuwen@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0023-7051
BD Animals and man; Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia; Australia
DE Amphibia; Reptilia [Expeditions /  / Sighting records & noteworthy
   observations] [Northern Territory /  / distribution; faunal list] [South
   Australia /  / ]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata
OR Amphibia (Vertebrata). 
   Reptilia (Vertebrata).

PT J
AN ZOOR15011069686
DT Article
TI Comparative study on the phylogenetic diversity of culturable
   actinobacteria associated with marine sponges and ascidians in six
   isolation media.
AU Yang Qi (qi.yang@flinders.edu.au) 
   Xin Yan-juan
   Franco, Christopher
   Ke Cai-huan
   Zhang Wei
SO Marine Sciences (Beijing)
VL 37
IS 7
PS 53-62
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB The diversity of culturable actinobacteria was investigated and compared
   between two sponges (Mycale sp. and Stylissa sp.) collected from Fujian
   province and two ascidians (Styela plicata and Molgula manhattensis)
   collected from Hainan province under the same isolation condition. Five
   actinobacteria selective isolation media and one general bacteria
   isolation medium were selected to isolate and culture actinobacteria
   from both sponges and ascidians. The phylogenetic affiliation of the
   actinobacterial isolates was assessed using a combination of 16S rRNA
   gene amplification-restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP)
   analysis and 16S rRNA gene sequencing. A total of 198 purified
   actinobacteria were cultivated, including 87 from sponges and 111 from
   ascidians. There are 38 different RFLP patterns and the phylogenetic
   analysis based on sequencing results reveal a high and distinctive
   diversity of actinobacteria associated with these two sponge species and
   two ascidian species, including six and seven actinomycetes genera,
   respectively. The BLAST results show that two actinobacterial isolates
   derived from sponges are probably novel strains whose similarity are
   lower than 97%, whereas there are eight isolates from ascidians regarded
   as potential novel actinobacteria. Comparing the diversity of
   actinobacteria associated with sponges and ascidians, most genera from
   sponge are also found in ascidians except Arthrobacter. The diversity of
   ascidian- associated actinobacteria is high and cannot be
   underestimated. Together with sponges, ascidians are also excellent and
   promising sources for novel marine actinobacteria currently under
   exploited for the discovery of new bioactive marine natural products.
C1 Yang Qi; Xiamen Univ, Coll Ocean & Earth, Xiamen, 361005, China, China.
EM qi.yang@flinders.edu.au
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1000-3096
BD Associations; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Molgula manhattensis; Styela plicata [Associations / Arthrobacter
   (bacterium) / Phylogenetic diversity] [North Pacific / China, Hainan /
   Bacterial associates]. 
   Mycale; Stylissa [Associations / Arthrobacter (bacterium) / Phylogenetic
   diversity] [North Pacific / China, Fujian / Bacterial associates]. 
TN Chordates; Invertebrates; Protochordates; Sponges; Tunicates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Urochordata, Ascidiacea, Porifera, Demospongiae
OR Molgula manhattensis (Ascidiacea). 
   Styela plicata (Ascidiacea). 
   Mycale (Demospongiae). 
   Stylissa (Demospongiae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15011069686
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI NEW DATA ON GENUS NIPHARGUS SCHIODTE, 1849 (FAM. NIPHARGIDAE) FROM ITALY
   AND MACEDONIA (CONTRIBUTION TO THE KNOWLEDGE OF THE AMPHIPODA 272).
AU Karaman, Gordan S. (karaman@t-com.me) 
SO Poljoprivreda i Sumarstvo
VL 59
IS 4
PS 29-54
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two members of the genus Niphargus Schiodte, 1849 (Family Niphargidae)
   are treated. The species Niphargus orbis, sp. n. is described, and
   figured from the subterranean waters of the springs in Rio di Valle,
   Alpi Ligure, Italy, previously mentioned (1993) under the name of N.
   rhenorhodanensis Schellenberg, 1937 from the same locality. The
   differences between both species are analysed. The species Niphargus
   osogovensis S. Karaman, 1959, known and partially described from the
   springs in Osogovo Mountain in Macedonia, is redescribed and figured
   more in detail from the type-locality based on typical material, and the
   taxonomical position of this species within the genus Niphargus is
   discussed.

TI The genus Schizopera (Copepoda, Harpacticoida) in the Pilbara region of
   Western Australia, with description of a new species and its molecular
   and morphological affinities.
AU Karanovic, T. (Tomislav.Karanovic@utas.edu.au) 
   McRae, J.
SO Records of the Western Australian Museum
VL 28
IS 2
PS 119-140
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The predominantly marine genus Schizopera Sars, 1905 has only two
   significant inland water species flocks, one in the ancient African Lake
   Tanganyika and the other in subterranean waters of Western Australia.
   Despite a great potential for studies of freshwater invasions, very
   little research has been done on these copepods, especially in the
   Pilbara region. We describe here S. cooperi sp. nov. from a bore hole
   about 45 km NW of Paraburdoo, which sheds new light on the previous
   sparse records of this genus in the region. Morphological characters
   suggest a close relationship between the new species and S. weelumurra
   Karanovic, 2006, a species described on the basis of a single female
   from a locality that lies some 100 km NE, with only minor differences in
   the proportion of some setae and spines. Phylogenetic analyses of the
   mtCOI partial sequences suggest that the new species has no close
   relatives among Western Australian congeners, molecular data for the
   presumably closely related S. weelumurra are missing. Molecular data
   suggest a closer relationship between S. cooperi and three congeners
   from the Yilgarn region than between it and another ( as yet
   unidentified) congener from the Pilbara, suggesting multiple
   colonisation events in both regions. An overview of the genus in the
   Pilbara highlights the need for more extensive sampling and for the use
   of molecular data to resolve issues of disjunct distribution patterns
   and delineation of morphologically similar species.
C1 Karanovic, T.; Hanyang Univ, Dept Life Sci, Seoul, 133791, South Korea,
   South Korea.
EM Tomislav.Karanovic@utas.edu.au
SC Zoology
SN 0312-3162
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Australasia; Australia
DE Schizopera [Australia /  / Key to species]. 
   Schizopera cooperi [Western Australia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Harpacticoida
OR Schizopera - Sars 1905 (Harpacticoida): [Key to species, Australia,
   Females, p. 138]. 
   Schizopera cooperi (Harpacticoida): [Sp nov, Western Australia, P. 124].

TI Limbodessus bennetti sp nov., the first stygobitic Dytiscidae
   (Coleoptera) from the Pilbara region of Western Australia.
AU Watts, C.H.S. (Chris.Watts@samuseum.sa.gov.au) 
   McRae, J.
SO Records of the Western Australian Museum
VL 28
IS 2
PS 141-143
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of subterranean carnivorous water beetle, Limbodessus
   bennetti sp. nov. (Dytiscidae) is described from an alluvial aquifer in
   the northern Pilbara of Western Australia. The new species is most
   closely related, by morphological and DNA evidence, to species of
   stygobitic Limbodessus from the Yilgarn region of Western Australia.

DT Article
TI Morphological and molecular assessment of Aprasia fusca and A. rostrata
   (Squamata: Pygopodidae), with a description of a new species from the
   Lake MacLeod region, Western Australia.
AU Maryan, Brad (Lerista.2@bigpond.com) 
   Bush, Brian G.
   Adams, Mark
SO Records of the Western Australian Museum
VL 28
IS 2
PS 144-163
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Australian pygopodid genus Aprasia comprises a group of small,
   morphologically conservative, worm-like fossorial lizards, many of which
   are distributed along the west coast of the continent. This study
   re-examines the taxonomic distinctiveness of the two most northerly
   occurring species in Western Australia: A. fusca and A. rostrata, which
   are very similar in morphology. A combined morphological and allozyme
   analysis revealed these two species to be conspecific with A. rostrata
   considered a senior synonym of A. fusca. As a consequence, we have
   redescribed A. rostrata. The allozyme analysis also revealed a new
   species, named here as Aprasia litorea sp. nov. This species occurs in
   the Lake Macleod region, well to the south of its congener, A. rostrata,
   and the two species are diagnosable using a conservative suite of
   morphological and meristic characters.
C1 Maryan, Brad; Biol Environm Survey, 50B Angove St, North Perth, WA,
   6006, Australia, Australia.
EM Lerista.2@bigpond.com
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology
SN 0312-3162
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Synonymy; General
   morphology; Biochemistry; Proteins; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Australasia; Australia
DE Aprasia fusca; Aprasia rostrata [General morphology /  / taxonomic
   implications] [Enzymes / Allozymes / ] [Western Australia / Lake Macleod
   region / ]. 
   Aprasia litorea [Western Australia /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Pygopodidae
OR Aprasia fusca (Pygopodidae). 
   Aprasia litorea (Pygopodidae): [Sp nov, Western Australia, P. 155]. 
   Aprasia rostrata - Parker 1956 (Pygopodidae): [Redescription, P. 152;
   Syn nov, Aprasia rostrata fusca Storr 1979, p. 150].

AB This paper describes the first report of Eustrongylides sp. larvae in
   Hoplias malabaricus Bloch, 1794 (Characiformes: Erythrinidae) in
   Rondonia State, Western Amazon, Brazil, and it is more a parasite which
   can infect humans in that area.

UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15011058812
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15010049962
DT Article
TI A description of four new species of Dindymus (Hemiptera: Heteroptera:
   Pyrrhocoridae) from south-eastern Asia.
AU Stehlik, Jaroslav L.
SO Acta Musei Moraviae Scientiae Biologicae
VL 98
IS 1
PS 41-51
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new species of the speciose genus Dindymus Stal, 1861 are
   described: Dindymus (Dindymus) flavinotum sp.nov. from Thailand,
   Dindymus (Dindymus) nigriventris sp.nov. from Vietnam, Dindymus
   (Dindymus) rubricus sp.nov. from Indonesia (East Kalimantan), and
   Dindymus (Pseudodindymus) vinulusoides sp.nov. from Malaysia
   (Kalimantan: Sarawak). Dindymus seminiger Blote, 1931 is recorded for
   the first time from Kalimantan (Malaysia: Sabah).
C1 Stehlik, Jaroslav L.; Moravian Museum, Dept Entomol, Hviezdoslavova 29A,
   Brno, CZ-62700, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
SC Zoology
SN 1211-8788
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;

DT Article
TI Taxonomic and nomenclatorial revision within the Neotropical genera of a
   subtribe Odontochilina W. Horn in a new sense-4. A new species and a new
   synonymy within the genus Odontocheila (Coleoptera: Cicindelidae).
AU Moravec, Jiri (jirmor@quick.cz) 
SO Acta Musei Moraviae Scientiae Biologicae
VL 98
IS 1
PS 53-73
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three species of Odontocheila Laporte de Castelnau, 1834 are presented.
   Odontocheila howdeni Nidek, 1980 syn.nov. is here synonymized with O.
   hamulipenis W. Horn, 1933, and an externally similar O. davidbrzoskai
   sp.nov. is described as a new species for science. While O. hamulipenis
   is known only from Colombia, the new species, distinguished particularly
   by the different shape of its aedeagus, is described from two rather
   distant localities in Panama. Detailed redescriptions of O. hamulipenis
   according to the male holotype (by monotypy) and other specimens, as
   well as of another barely known species O. angulipenis W. Horn, 1932,
   are presented, and a lectotype of the latter here designated.
   Illustrations of diagnostic characters of the type and other specimens
   of all these taxa are presented in colour photographs. In addition, O.
   iodopleuroides Mandl, 1972 (originally lacking a locality label), is
   here excluded from the genus Odontocheila, because examination of the
   holotype (by monotypy) has revealed that it is East Asian species
   Prothyma heteromala MacLaey, 1825.
C1 Moravec, Jiri; Sadova 336-21, Adamov, 67904 1, Czech Republic, Czech
   Republic.

DT Article
TI Taxonomic and nomenclatorial revision within the Neotropical genera of a
   subtribe Odontochilina W. Horn in a new sense-5. A new species of the
   genus Pentacomia from Costa Rica (Coleoptera: Cicindelidae).
AU Moravec, Jiri (jirmor@quick.cz) 
   Brzoska, David
SO Acta Musei Moraviae Scientiae Biologicae
VL 98
IS 1
PS 75-84
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Pentacomia (Mesochila) wappesi sp.nov. is described as a new species to
   science, representing the second species of the genus to be recorded
   from Costa Rica. By the pattern of the whitish elytral maculation and
   mandibles with only three teeth, this new species resembles P. (M.)
   skrabali Duran et Moravec, 2013 described from Panama, but P. (M)
   wappesi sp.nov. clearly differs both in its external and internal
   characters, immediately in having nearly smooth and shiny pronotum with
   only several, mostly fine transverse median wrinkles. Examination of
   type specimens of relevant species of Pentacomia has confirmed that by
   the complex of its characters, P. (M.) wappesi sp.nov. is markedly
   distinguished from all known species in the genus. It represents an
   intermediate link between the subgenera Pentacomia s. str., Mesochila
   Rivalier, 1969, and Beckerium Rivalier, 1969. Particularly due to the
   tridentate mandibles, both P. (M.) skrabali and P (M.) wappesi sp.nov.
   may represent a separate subgenus. Illustrations of the habitus and
   diagnostic characters of the new species and distinguishing external
   characters of P. (M.) skrabali are presented in colour photographs.
C1 Moravec, Jiri; Sadova 336-21, Adamov, 67904 1, Czech Republic, Czech
   Republic.

   Central America

TI Apogonia reticulata Frey, 1969-a new and surprising junior subjective
   synonym for A. cribricollis Burmeister, 1855 (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae:
   Melolonthinae: Diplotaxini).
AU Bezdek, Ales (bezdek@entu.cas.cz) 
SO Acta Musei Moraviae Scientiae Biologicae
VL 98
IS 1
PS 85-97
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Examination of type specimens of Apogonia reticulata Frey, 1969 leads to
   the conclusion that the name is a junior subjective synonym of Apogonia
   cribricollis Burmeister, 1855. The type locality of A. reticulata is
   discussed and the assertion made that this species has previously been
   described on the basis of mislabelled specimens collected in the
   Oriental region. Apogonia cribricolis is redescribed, compared with
   closely related species, and its geographical distribution is mapped.

DT Article
TI Coccolithophorids in Polar Waters: Wigwamma spp. Revisited.
AU Thomsen, Helge A. (hat@aqua.dtu.dk) 
   Ostergaard, Jette B.
   Heldal, Mikal
SO Acta Protozoologica
VL 52
IS 4
PS 237-256
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A contingent of weakly calcified coccolithophorid genera and species
   were described from polar regions almost 40 years ago. In the interim
   period a few additional findings have been reported enlarging the realm
   of some of the species. The genus Wigwamma is revisited here with the
   purpose of providing, based on additional sampling from both polar
   regions, an update on species morphology, life history events and
   biogeography that can serve as a reference for the future. A new genus,
   Pseudowigwamma gen. nov. is described to accommodate Wigwamma
   scenozonion, a species which critically deviates from a core group of
   five Wigwamma species in terms of coccolith morphology and life history
   events. Wigwamma armatura sp. nov. is described on the basis of material
   from the Weddell Sea, Antarctica. While fitting nicely into the Wigwamma
   generic concept, the species adds new dimensions to the overall
   appearance of the coccolith armour of the cell.
C1 Thomsen, Helge A.; DTU Aqua, Jaegersborg Alle 1, Charlottenlund,
   DK-2920, Denmark, Denmark.
EM hat@aqua.dtu.dk
SC Zoology
SN 0065-1583; 1689-0027

   Zoogeography; Marine zones
DE Wigwamma [Zoogeography /  / Systematics] [Antarctic Ocean /  / ] [Arctic
   Ocean /  / ]. 
   Wigwamma armatura [Antarctic Ocean / Antarctica / New species]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Mastigophora, Phytomastigophorea,
   Prymnesiida

   Wigwamma scenozonion Thomsen 1980, p. 252].

   Wigwamma - Manton, Sutherland & Oates 1977 (Prymnesiida).

   Wigwamma scenozonion - Thomsen 1980 (Prymnesiida): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Pseudowigwamma, p. 252].

DT Article
TI Choleoeimeria bunopusi sp n. (Apicomplexa: Eimeriidae) Infecting the
   Gall Bladder of the Tuberculated Gecko Bunopus tuberculatus (Reptilia:
   Gekkonidae) from Saudi Arabia.
AU Al-Quraishy, Saleh
   Abdel-Baki, Abdel-Azeem S. (azema1@yahoo.com) 
   Al Otaibi, Mamdooh S.A.
SO Acta Protozoologica
VL 52
IS 4
PS 267-272
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Choleoeimeria bunopusi sp. n. is described from the gall bladder of the
   tuberculated gecko Bunopus tuberculatus in Saudi Arabia. The prevalence
   of infection was 13.3% (2/15). Oocysts were ellipsoidal and measured 31
   (30-33) x 21 (20-22) [mu]m. Sporocysts were dizoic, elliptical in shape
   and measured 12 (11-13) x 7 (6-8) [mu]m. The endogenous development was
   confined to the gall bladder epithelium. The hypertrophic parasitized
   biliary epithelium either remained in one layer or became stratified.
   Meronts, gamonts, and young oocysts were detected.

DT Article
TI Eimeria spp. (Apicomplexa: Eimeriidae) in Black Caiman Melanosuchus
   niger (Crocodilia: Alligatoridae) from the Amazon Region, Brazil, with a
   Description of Two New Coccidian Species.
AU Viana, Lucio Andre (lucviana74@gmail.com) 
   da Silva Motta, Adarene Guimaraes
   Coutinho, Marcos Eduardo
   Duarte Rocha, Carlos Frederico
SO Acta Protozoologica
VL 52
IS 4
PS 283-289
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB During November 2011, faeces from 23 black caimans (Melanosuchus niger)
   were collected from the Brazilian Amazon, and coccidians were found in
   83% of the individuals examined. Three Eimeria species were found in the
   black caiman faeces, two of which were recognised as new species and are
   subsequently described in the present study. Eimeria paraguayensis was
   found in 17 of 23 animals sampled. Eimeria nigeri n. sp were found in
   16/23 animals examined. Oocysts were spherical to sub-spherical, 29.2 x
   28.1 (23-32 x 23-30) [mu]m, and 12.1 x 11.0 [mu]m spherical oocyst
   residuum was present. Sporocyst was ovoid, 15.5 x 9.7 (8-11 x 12-17)
   [mu]m, and had a Stieda body at a slightly pointed end. The sporocyst
   residuum consisted of a compact mass of refractile granules. Eimeria
   portovelhensis n. sp. were found in 16/23 animals examined. Oocysts were
   spheroidal, 19.5 x 19.1 (16-21) [mu]m, and had 9.0 x 7.8 [mu]m spherical
   oocyst residuum present. The spindle-shaped sporocysts were 11.0 x 4.0
   (8-13 x 2-5) [mu]m and had two apparent Stieda bodies, one at each pole
   and with one filament curved at each pole. Sporocyst residuum was
   present, with four or five small refractile granules. The two new
   species are differentiated from the five species of Eimeria recorded
   within the crocodilian family Alligatoridae.
C1 Viana, Lucio Andre; Univ Estado Rio de Janeiro, Dept Ecol, Rua Sao
   Francisco Xavier 524, Rio De Janeiro, BR-20541000 BC, Brazil, Brazil.

   America

   niger / New parasite species] [Brazil /  / New species from reptilian
   host].

DT Article
TI Morphometric Studies in Enterobryus luteovirgatus sp nov (Ichthyosporea:
   Eccrinales) Associated with Yellow-banded Millipedes in Puerto Rico.
AU Contreras, Kenny
   Cafaro, Matias J. (matias.cafaro@upr.edu) 
SO Acta Protozoologica
VL 52
IS 4
PS 291-297
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Symbiosis is the association between two non-related organisms. The
   common yellow-banded millipede, Anadenobolus monilicornis (Diplopoda:
   Spirobolida: Rhinocricidae) and the protist Enterobryus luteovirgatus
   sp. nov. (Ichthyosporea: Eccrinales), a species of hair-like
   microorganism that inhabits its gut, form a commensalistic relationship.
   The genus Enterobryus was once part of a fungal class (Trichomycetes),
   but now it is classified as a protist. Other Enterobryus species have
   been reported associated with non-carnivorous arthropod hosts including
   beetles, crabs and millipedes. Yellow-banded millipedes from Guanica Dry
   Forest, Puerto Rico were collected to study the prevalence of
   Enterobryus species. A new Enterobryus species that inhabits A.
   monilicornis is herein described. Traditionally, Enterobryus species are
   difficult to identify due to high intraspecific variation. Thus,
   statistical analysis of character measurements is included in an attempt
   to investigate character stability. Millipedes were dissected; gut
   linings with attached Enterobryus were placed on slides and preserved.
   Morphometric data of thalli, sporangiospores and holdfasts presented a
   normal distribution of parameters except for the basal disk width of the
   holdfast, which showed extreme variation. This character, although used
   to described Enterobryus species is not reliable in E. luteovirgatus
   when using the mean or range values in taxon descriptions.
C1 Cafaro, Matias J.; Univ Puerto Rico, Dept Biol, Call Box 9000, Mayaguez,
   PR, 00681, USA, USA.
EM matias.cafaro@upr.edu
OI Cafaro, Matias/0000-0002-2987-716X
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0065-1583; 1689-0027
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Associations; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; Central America; West Indies
DE Anadenobolus monilicornis [Associations / Enterobryus luteovirgatus
   (Protozoa) / New associate species] [Puerto Rico /  / New associated
   protozoan species]. 
   Enterobryus luteovirgatus [Associations / Anadenobolus monilicornis
   (Arthropoda) / New associate species] [Puerto Rico /  / New species;
   arthropod associate]. 
TN Arthropods; Invertebrates; Myriapods; Protozoans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Myriapoda, Diplopoda, Protozoa
OR Anadenobolus monilicornis (Diplopoda). 
   Enterobryus luteovirgatus - Cafaro & Contreras 2013 (Protozoa): [Sp nov,
   Puerto Rico, Associated with Anadenobolus monilicornis (Diplopoda), p.
   293].

DT Article
TI Tubulinosema loxostegi sp n. (Microsporidia: Tubulinosematidae) from the
   Beet Webworm Loxostege sticticalis L. (Lepidoptera: Crambidae) in
   Western Siberia.
AU Malysh, Julia M.
   Tokarev, Yuri S. (jumacro@yahoo.com) 
   Sitnicova, Natalia V.
   Martemya-Nov, Vyacheslav V.
   Frolov, Andrei N.
   Issi, Irma V.
SO Acta Protozoologica
VL 52
IS 4
PS 299-308
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Adults of beet webworm Loxostege sticticalis were collected in Western
   Siberia in 2009 and 2010. A microsporidium was found infecting 12 of 50
   moths in 2010. The parasite develops in direct contact with host cell
   cytoplasm, sporogony is presumably disporoblastic. The spores are ovoid,
   diplokaryotic, 4.2 x 2.4 [mu]m in size (fresh), without a sporophorous
   vesicle. Electron microscopy showed: (a) tubules on the surface of
   sporoblasts and immature spores; (b) slightly anisofilar polar tube with
   10-14 coils, last 2-3 coils of lesser electron density; (c) bipartite
   polaroplast with anterior and posterior parts composed of thin and thick
   lamellae, respectively; (d) an indentation in the region of the
   anchoring disc; (e) an additional layer of electron-dense amorphous
   matter on the exospore surface. The spore ultrastructure is
   characteristic of the genus Tubulinosema. Sequencing of small subunit
   and large subunit ribosomal RNA genes showed 98-99.6% similarity of this
   parasite to the Tubulinosema species available on Genbank. A new species
   Tubulinosema loxostegi sp. n. is established.
C1 Tokarev, Yuri S.; All Russian Inst Plant Protect, Lab Microbiol Control,
   Podbelskogo 3, St Petersburg, 196608, Russia, Russia.
EM jumacro@yahoo.com

   Vyacheslav/Q-7466-2016; Malysh, Yuliya M/S-5939-2017
OI Frolov, Andrey/0000-0002-6942-9951; Tokarev, Yuri/0000-0003-0524-0778;
   Malysh, Yuliya M/0000-0002-7353-421X

SN 0065-1583; 1689-0027

   disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia

TI Revision of genus Cerais VAN DER WULP (Diptera: Chloropidae:
   Chloropinae: Mindini) with description of two new species from India.
AU Cherian, Panameduthathil Thomas (cherian_pt07@yahoo.co.in)

LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Aragara WALKER is placed under the tribe Mindini and Aragara magnicornis
   (VAN DER WULP) is transferred back from Aragara to Cerais. Genus
   Bathyparia LAMB is synonymised with Cerais VAN DER WULP and Cerais ponti
   and Cerais travancorensis, two new species from India, are described. A

PT J
AN ZOOR15010051735
DT Article
TI New dormice records (Rodentia: Gliridae) from the Late Miocene of the
   Republic of Moldova.
AU Delinschi, Andrian (andriandelinschi@yahoo.com) 
SO Acta Zoologica Cracoviensia
VL 56
IS 2
PS 13-28
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Gliridae from three Late Miocene localities of the Republic of
   Moldova Chimishliya (age MN12), Gura Galbene (MN12), and Gradishte
   (MN11/12) are described and their taxonomic position discussed: two are
   assigned to Myomimus, one each to Vasseuromys, Muscardinus and Gliridae
   gen. and sp. indet. The most abundant fossil remains were found in
   Chimishliya (nine teeth) and the most taxonomic diversity was observed
   in Gura Galbene (Myomimus dehmi/maritsensis, Myomimus sp., Muscardinus
   and Gliridae gen. and sp. indet). Discovery of the specimen of
   Muscardinus from Moldova fills the stratigraphic gap of genus occurrence
   between MN11 and MN14 in Europe. Scarcity of fossil remains does not
   allow for reconstruction of the transformations of the dormice fauna,
   though presence of particular genera is indicative of specific
   palaeoenvironment conditions in the Late Miocene of Moldova.
C1 Delinschi, Andrian; Natl Museum Ethnog & Nat Hist Moldova, Dept Nat Sci,
   M Kogalniceanu Str 82, Chisinau, 2009, Moldova, Moldova.
EM andriandelinschi@yahoo.com
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Paleontology
SN 2299-6060; 2300-0163
BD Systematics; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe;
   Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Gliridae [Environmental indicators / Palaeoenvironmental indications /
   New record; systematics] [Moldova /  / ] [Miocene / Late Miocene / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Rodents; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Rodentia
OR Gliridae (Rodentia): [Fossil; New record].

TI An assessment of the Tortricid (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae) fauna of Seram
   Island, Indonesia.
AU Razowski, Jozef (razowski@isez.pan.krakow.pl) 
SO Acta Zoologica Cracoviensia
VL 56
IS 2
PS 29-89
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The tortricid fauna of Seram is comprised of 35 genera and 60 species.
   Two genera (Kanikehia gen. n., Mersa gen. n.) and 41 species
   (Reptilisocia gunungana sp. n., Schoenotenes peos sp. n., Schoenotenes
   emmetra sp. n., Schoenotenes elasma sp. n., Metachorista longiseta sp.
   n., Cornuticlava binaiae sp. n., Cornuticlava kobipoto sp. n.,
   Mimeoclysia mystrion sp. n., Kanikehia kanikehiana sp. n., Mersa
   metochia sp. n., Homona obtusuncus sp. n., Homona privigena sp. n.,
   Isodemis solea sp. n., Isodemis phloiosignum sp. n., Isotenes syndesma
   sp. n., Isotenes latitata sp. n., Zacorisca leura sp. n., Zacorisca
   helicocesturn sp. n., Zacorisca seramica sp. n., Zacorisca digna sp. n.,
   Adoxophyes planes sp. n., Adoxophyes melon sp. n., Adoxophyes olethra
   sp. n., Adoxophyes lacertana sp. n., Adoxophyes panurga sp. n.,
   Adoxophyes luctuosa sp. n., Demeijerella palleophyton sp. n., Lobesia
   drasteria sp. n., Rhectogonia sandrae sp. n., Metrioglypha ithuncus sp.
   n., Aterpia monada sp. n., Asaphistis omora sp. n., Rhodacra leptalea
   sp. n., Rhopobotajonesiana sp. n., Rhopobota nasea sp. n., Rhopobota
   grisona sp. n., Peridaedala spec: data sp. n., Peridaedala stenygra sp.
   n., Fibuloides rusticola sp. n., Spilonota terenia sp. n., Cryptophlebia
   heterospina sp. n.) are described as new. Rhapsodica MEYRICK, 1927 is
   synonymized with Homona WALKER, 1863, and Rhapsodica ant itona MEYRICK,
   1927 is transferred to Homona WALKER, 1863. Biological data are included
   with each particular species.

TI Description of a new species of the genus Horistonotus (Coleoptera:
   Elateridae) and illustrated key to the identification of species present
   in Argentina.
FT Descripcion de una nueva especie del genero Horistonotus (Coleoptera:
   Elateridae) y clave ilustrada para la determinacion de especies
   presentes en la Argentina.
AU Cordoba, Silvia P. (silviapcordoba@hotmail.com) 
   Aranda, Susana G.
SO Acta Zoologica Lilloana
VL 57
IS 1
PS 3-13
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB Horistonotus sublateralis sp. nov., which belongs to the modified tarsal
   claws species group, is described. Illustrations of the general aspect,
   wings, and male and female genitalia, as well as Scanning Electron
   Microscope photographs to distinguish better some of the characters, are
   presented. In addition, a map of collection localities and an
   illustrated key for the identification of the argentinean species are
   provided.

AB Two new genera of Phlaeothripidae, Phlaeothripinae (Thysanoptera) and
   six species are described. They can be distinguished from the other
   genera in Phlaeothripidae by the form and position of the maxillary
   stylets. In each case, descriptions, measurements and illustrations of
   each species are included.

TI On the fauna of plume moths (Lepidoptera, Pterophoridae) of Zimbabwe.
AU Ustjuzhanin, P.Ya. (petrust@mail.ru) 
   Kovtunovich, V.N.
SO Amurskii Zoologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 5
IS 2
PS 153-160
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The list of Zimbabwean Pterophoridae includes 56 species, with 48
   species first recorded from Zimbabwe. The descriptions of 2 new species
   are given: Walsinghamiella selinda Ustjuzhanin & Kovtunovich sp. nov.
   and Platyptilia swynnertoni Ustjuzhanin & Kovtunovich sp. nov. New
   synonyms are established for 4 species: Platyptilia periacta Meyrick,
   1910, syn. nov., junior synonym to Platyptila farfarella Zeller, 1867;
   Platyptilia claripicta Fletcher, 1910, syn. nov., junior synonym to
   Platyptila farfarella Zeller, 1867; Marasmarcha pavidus (Meyrick, 1908),
   syn. nov., junior synonym to Marasmarcha bonaespei (Walsingham, 1881);
   Hellinsia purus (Meyrick, 1913), syn. nov., junior synonym to Crassuncus
   pacifica (Meyrick, 1911). New combinations are given for 3 species:
   Procapperia insomnis (Townsend, 1956) comb. nov.; Marasmarcha locharcha
   (Meyrick, 1924) comb. nov.; Crassuncus pacifica (Meyrick, 1911) comb.
   nov.

IS 2

LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The lectotype of Lycaena charybdis Staudinger, 1886 is designated and a
   new subspecies Glaucopsyche aeruginosa memorabilis Korb, ssp. nov. is
   described (type locality: Tadjikistan, Peter the Great Mts.,
   Garzani-Kaftar Pass near Lyangar village, 2800 - 3100 m). G. laetifica
   (Pungeler, 1901) is reported as a new species for Russian and European
   fauna by the materials collected in Saratov, Astrakhan and Volgograd
   Provinces.

DT Article
TI COLLEMBOLA FROM THE MOLDAVIAN BANKS OF DNIESTER RIVER. NEW RECORDS.
AU Busmachiu, Galina
   Weiner, Wanda Maria (bushmakiu@yahoo.com) 
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 63
IS 4
PS 529-535
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The study of Collembola communities of banks of the Dniester River
   revealed 54 species of Collembola belonging to 35 genera and 13
   families. Five species were common for all studied sites: Mesaphorura
   critica, Metaphorura affinis, Hemisotoma therrnophila, Isotomodes
   productus and Parisotoma notabilis. The whole list of Collembola is
   included, three species are new for Moldova. The study revealed three
   new species for the science of the genera Micraphorura, Agraphorura and
   Mesaphorura. Description of Micraphorura gamae sp. nov. the most similar
   to Micraphorura pieninesis Weiner, 1988 is provided.

   Slawkowska 17, Krakow, PL-31016, Poland, Poland.

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF CHEILOTRICHIA ROSSI, 1848 (DIPTERA: LIMONIIDAE) FROM
   BITTERFELD AMBER.
AU Kopec, Katarzyna
   Kania, Iwona (ikania@univ.rzeszow.pl) 
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 63
IS 4
PS 537-540
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species of the genus Cheilotrichia Rossi, 1848 (Diptera:
   Limoniidae) from Bitterfeld amber is described. Bitterfeld amber
   (Saxonian amber) is contemporaneous with the Baltic amber deposited in
   Gdansk Amber Bay area. The representatives of the same species are often
   found among inclusions of Bitterfeld and Baltic amber but the species
   described herein Cheiliotrichia (Empeda) weitschati sp. nov. have been
   found only in Bitterfeld amber.
C1 Kania, Iwona; Univ Rzeszow, Dept Environm Biol, Zelwerowicza 4, Rzeszow,
   PL-35601, Poland, Poland.

TI ATOPOMYCHUS LONGICORNIS, NEW GENUS AND NEW SPECIES OF LYCOPERDININAE
   FROM THE NEOTROPICS (COLEOPTERA: ENDOMYCHIDAE).
AU Tomaszewska, Wioletta (wiolkat@miiz.waw.pl) 
   Szawaryn, Karol
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 63
IS 4
PS 541-549
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Atopomyckus gen. nov. along with A. longieornis sp. nov. (Coleoptera:
   Endomychidae) from Ecuador is described and illustrated. Its placement
   within the subfamily Lycoperdininae is discussed. A key to genera of the
   Neotropical Lycoperdininae is updated.

DT Article
TI GENERA OF DASCILLINAE (COLEOPTERA: DASCILLIDAE) WITH A REVIEW OF THE
   ASIAN SPECIES OF DASCILLUS LATREILLE, PETALON SCHONHERR AND SINOCAULUS
   FAIRMAIRE.
AU Jin, Zhenyu
   Slipinski, Adam
   Pang, Hong (ahk_731@163.com) 
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 63
IS 4
PS 551-652
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Phylogenetic relationships within the Dascillinae were investigated.
   Eighteen ingroup taxa and two outgroups were included in cladistic
   analysis, based on 30 characters derived from adult morphology. Six
   genera are recognised in Dascillinae: Coptocera Murray, Dascillus
   Latreille, Metallidascillus Pic, Notodascillus Carter, Petalon
   Schoenherr and Sinocaulus Farimaire. Pseudolich,as Fairmaire, 1878 (TS:
   P. sulcifrons Fairmaire, 1878) is recognised as a junior synonym of
   Petalon Schoenherr, 1833 (TS: Bruchus fulvulus Wiedemann, 1819) syn.
   nov. All valid genera of Dascillinae are thoroughly described,
   illustrated and key to their identification is provided. Species level
   keys are provided for Old Wold Dascillus, Petalon and Sinocautus.
   Eighteen new species are described: Dascillus acutus (China: Shanxi), D.
   chifengi (China: Taiwan), D. compressus (Nepal), D. formosanus (China:
   Taiwan), D. lancezts (China: Taiwan), D. largus (China: Hubei), D.
   nzontwim (China: Sichuan), D. planus (China: Yunnan), D. russus (India:
   Arunachal Pradesh), D. tibetensis (China: Tibet), D. transversus (China:
   Yunnan), Petalon acerbus (China-Yunnan), P. allochroides (Malaysia,
   Sabah), P. annamensis (Vietnam), P. digitatus (China: Yunnan), P. iviei
   (China: Yunnan), Sinocaulus clypeatus (China: Guizhou) and S.
   OTitiellSi.9 (China: Sichuan). The following species level new synonyms
   are proposed (senior synonym listed first): DaSellIZIS COVTUUS Pascoe,
   1860 (= Da.scillus perroudi Pie, 1939, D. klapperichi, Pic, 1955, D.
   tailvanus Nakane, 1995 and D. fortunei Pic, 1913); Dascillus calvescens
   Bourgeois, 1892 (= D. holzi Pic, 1911, D. rufocinctus Pic, 1913, D.
   brevesulcatus Pic, 1933 and D. rubropubens Pic, 1934); Dascillus
   renctrdi Bourgeois, 1891(= D. rufovillosus Bourgeois, 1892); Dascillus
   fulvulus (Wiedemann, 1819) (= D. striatus Pic, 1911, D. cozporaali Pic,
   1923 and D. ob.scuricolor Pic, 1933); D. obscuripes Pic, 1912 (= D.
   ?writs Pic, 1923); Pseudolichas nivipictus Fairmaire, 1904 (=
   Pseudolichas ruficornis Pic, 1914) and Sinocaulus rubrovelutinus
   Fairmaire, 1878 (= Haenzatoides atriceps Pic, 1910: 45). Four taxa are
   transferred to Dascillus Latreille (Cladotoma vittata Pic, 1914;
   Pseudolichas nigronotatus Pic, 1914; Pseudolichas nivipictus Fairmaire,
   1904; Pseudolichas superbus Pic, 1907 and Thertus jaspidems Fairmaire,
   1878) comb. nov. Fifeteen species are transferred to Petalon Schonherr
   (Dascillus bengalensis Pic, 1911; D. birnzanicus Pic, 1913; D.
   calvescems Bourgeois, 1892; D. fruhstorferi Pic, 1912; D. fulvithorax
   Pic, 1933; D. indicus Guerin-Meneville, 1861; D. leopoldi Pic, 1933; D.
   major Pic, 1933; D. obscuripes Pic, 1912; D. pritinosus Fairmaire, 1896;
   D. renardi Bourgeois, 1891; D. rufithorax Pic, 1912; D. rufovillosus
   Bourgeois, 1892; D. rufus Pic, 1923 and Pseudolichas sulcifrons
   Fairmaire, 1878) comb. nov. The neotypes are designated for: Bruchus
   fulvulus Wiedemann, 1819 (Indonesia: Java) and Dascillus maculosus
   Fairmaire, 1889 (China: Sichuan). Lectotypes are designated for:
   Dascillus bengalensis Pic, 1911; D. brevesulcatus Pic, 1933; D.
   calvescens Bourgeois, 1892; D. cavaleriei Pic, 1930; D. corporaali Pic,
   1923; D. costatus Pic, 1927; D. fortunei Pic 1913; D. holzi Pic, 1911;
   D. klapperichi Pic, 1955; D. nigripennis Guerin-Meneville, 1861; D.
   obscuricolor Pic, 1933; D. obscuripes Pic, 1912; D. pallidofemoratus
   Pic, 1911; D. perroudi Pic, 1939; D. renardi Bourgeois, 1891; D.
   rubropubens Pic, 1934; D. rufocinctus Pic, 1913; D. rufovillosus
   Bourgeois, 1892; D. rufus Pic, 1923; D. striatus Pic, 1911; D.
   sublineatus Pic, 1915; Haematoides atriceps Pic, 1910; Pseudolichas
   sulcifrons Fairmaire, 1878 and Sinocaulus rubrovelutinus Fairmaire,
   1878.
C1 Pang, Hong; Sun Yat Sen Univ, Guangdong Higher Educ Inst, Guangzhou,
   Guangdong, 510275, China, China.

TI CHTHONIUS (EPHIPPIOCHTHONIUS) RHIZON N. SP.: A NEW CAVE FALSE SCORPION
   FROM THE BAY OF KOTOR (CHTHONIIDAE, PSEUDOSCORPIONES).
AU Curcic, B.P.M.
   Makarov, S.E.
   Curcic, Nina B.
   Curcic, S.B.
   Tomic, V.T.
SO Archives of Biological Sciences
VL 65
IS 4
PS 1547-1551
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new cave pseudoscorpion from Montenegro, Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius)
   rhizon n. sp., is described. The newly erected taxon is endemic to the
   Bukaricka Pecina Cave, Knezlaz, Montenegro. Its taxonomic relationship
   with the phenetically close congeners, including comparative
   morphological traits, is described.
C1 Curcic, B.P.M.; Univ Belgrade, Inst Zool, Belgrade, 11000, Serbia,
   Serbia.

AB A new endemic epigean pseudoscorpion species from Mt. Orjen, Montenegro,
   is presented, described, and illustrated. Its main morphometric
   characters and important diagnostic features are analyzed and compared
   to its closest congeners.

DT Article
TI REMARKS ON SOME TRECHINE GROUND BEETLE TAXA FROM THE BALKAN PENINSULA
   (COLEOPTERA: CARABIDAE: TRECHINI).
AU Curcic, S.B.
   Curcic, B.P.M.
   Vrbica, Maja
SO Archives of Biological Sciences
VL 65
IS 4
PS 1675-1686
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The purpose of this note is to offer some corrections and supplements to
   the paper of Lohaj et al. (2013), to prove the validity of recently
   described trechine genera in Serbia, and to comment on other erroneous
   facts presented in the analyzed paper. In particular, we will show that
   the taxonomical remarks on the genus Duvalius Delarouzee, 1859, are
   wrong. The following genera are clearly delimited and represent valid
   taxa: Serboduvalius Curcic, Pavicevic & Curcic, 2001, comb. n.,
   Rascioduvalius Curcic, Brajkovic, Mitic & Curcic, 2003, comb. n.,
   Curcicia Curcic & Brajkovic, 2003, comb. n., and Javorella Curcic,
   Brajkovic & Curcic, 2003, comb. n. The following new combinations are
   established for the following Duvalius species: Serboduvalius
   gejzadunayi (Lohaj, Ceplik & Lakota, 2013), comb. n., S. starivlahi
   (Gueorguiev, Curcic & Curcic, 2000), comb. n., S. dragacevensis Curcic,
   Pavicevic & Curcic, 2001, comb. n., S. droveniki (Magrini, 1998), comb.
   n., Rascioduvalius cvijici (Jeannel, 1923), comb. n., R. stopicensis
   (Jeannel, 1923), comb. n., R. zlatiborensis Curcic, Brajkovic & Curcic,
   2005, comb. n., Curcicia bolei (Pretner, 1963), comb. n., Javorella
   javorensis Curcic, Brajkovic & Curcic, 2003, comb. n., J. suvoborensis
   (Pavicevic & Popovic, 2001), comb. n., and J. suvodolensis Curcic,
   Brajkovic & Curcic, 2003, comb. n.

DT Article
TI ON SOME NEW CAVE-DWELLING GROUND BEETLES (COLEOPTERA: CARABIDAE:
   TRECHINI) FROM EASTERN SERBIA.
AU Vrbica, Maja
   Curcic, S.
   Antic, D.
   Petrovic, A.
   Tomic, V.
   Petkovic, M.
   Markovic, D.
   Stojanovic, D.
   Curcic, B.
SO Archives of Biological Sciences
VL 65
IS 4
PS 1687-1701
PD 2013
PY 2013
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The following new cavernicolous ground beetle taxa are described from
   three caves in eastern Serbia: Duvalius (Paraduvalius) trifunovici sp.
   n., from the Mandina Pecina Cave, village of Zlot, near Bor, Kucajske
   Planine Mts., D. (P.) rtanjensis sp. n., from the Golema Porica Pit, Mt.
   Rtanj, and Glabroduvalius gen. n., G. tupiznicensis sp. n., from the
   Gornja Lenovacka Pecina Cave, village of Lenovac, near Zajecar, Mt.
   Tupiznica. The new taxa are easily distinguished from related organisms.
   All important morphological features have been listed, along with the
   diagnoses and illustrations of the taxa. The new taxa are relicts and
   endemics of eastern Serbia and probably belong to old phyletic lineages
   of Tertiary or even pre-Tertiary origin.
